reviews.review_text: FEAR 3 represents what is wrong with many 'modernization' processes of games. It takes everything that people liked about the first few games in the series and just replaces or modifies them to work with current trends, such as in this case regenerating health, co-op, perks... However, I would also argue FEAR 3 is not a bad game. If you're looking for a game akin to FEAR 1 or 2, this unfortunately is not it. It also is pretty lacking in the horror department. It's not scary, or even really atmospheric, though it attempts to be. What it is though, is a pretty fun multiplayer experience.  The story will probably ♥♥♥♥-off long-time fans. Without going too deep into spoilers, the story basically focuses mostly on Fettel, the antagonist from the first game. The story's already kind of in a mess from the get-go, as we have things from psychic powers, clones, the fact our two main characters are the sons of the series main antagonist Alma, and just other plot elements that just scream they're so bad. But it's not badly written to be fair, and if you kind of turn off your brain it's kind of stupid entertainment. But you really shouldn't be playing this game for the story.  The campaign should last for about 5-7 hours, with some highs and lows, but that in no way compares to the previous two games. The co-op helps make it a bit more fun, for better or worse. The two brothers play completely differently though, with Pointman basically being your typical action hero with the guns and the slide-kicks, and Fettel being actually surprisingly rather fresh, being a psychic man who can levitate enemies, possess them, shoot energy blasts, and more. Honestly, both are pretty fun, but I have to hand it to Fettel as for a game with very little inspiration behind it, his gameplay is actually rather original for this sort of game and fun.  But it's not the campaign you should be buying FEAR 3 for, as weird as that might sound. I find most people never delve into the multiplayer modes in this game. And it's sensible, as the campaign is disappointing and usually multiplayer modes are tagged on without much thought or effort, so it's probably nothing special, right?  Well, that's wrong, as it turns out the multiplayer modes in this game are actually the best part of the game.  I can't even count how many friends who got FEAR 3 that ended up loving the multiplayer modes and hating the campaign. Let me explain; The campaign lacks tension, and often is a bit repetitive, on-top of the fact it just feels rather uninspired most of the time, its horror elements fail, and its action sequences aren't particularly great. But something FEAR 3 does surprisingly well is understand the fun elements of multiplayer shooters. Hell, some of the multiplayer modes are even far more tense and more horror-like than anything in the campaign.  Multiplayer is split into four modes, and all four are pretty fun for up to four-players either locally or online. Each mode has different maps. One mode has you all as ghost phantoms who possess bodies and try to kill other enemies and your friends to collect souls, most souls at the end of a wave wins the round, and at the end of all waves, person with the most rounds won wins. Another mode has you in an open arena with multiple areas to station yourself in as you and friends fight hordes of enemies that come in waves, boarding up windows and between waves going out to collect supplies. It's a sort of rip-off of Zombie mode from CoD, but it has some interesting twists, such as Alma, who you should not look at as she'll cause randomized effects against you, ranging from just downing you to making you see your friends as enemies, making the screen go black, or teleporting you to another random point on the map. Or a fog, that gets thicker and thicker as the waves go on, and an unseen red-light monster lurks in the deeper parts of the fog... And in yet another mode, you and up to three friends run away from a giant wall of death. Really challenging, frantic, tense, panic-worthy, but a lot of fun as a lot of enemies get tossed your way and you only get small breathers to quickly recollect supplies before the wall is out it again. A race from death and survival that is both primal but also strategic and fun.  The game also looks pretty good, and the PC port is well-done. Music works, but nothing outside of the credits song sticks as being particularly memorable.  FEAR 3 is against most everything the FEAR series stands for, but if you can look over that and a disappointing campaign, I guarantee you there's some multiplayer fun here that may be worth experiencing.

Remember F.E.A.R. when it first came out and you wanted to play it even though your system couldn't even handle it? Perhaps, that was not the case for you, but it was for me. Eventually, I was able to run it with decent hardware and I never looked back.  F.E.A.R. stepped into the seen in slow-mo and then it took the first-person shooter genre by storm, tailored to shooter and survival-horror fans. F.E.A.R. 3, while the weaker follow-up to the F.E.A.R. series still holds up as an atmospheric game with solid gunplay and an interestingly shocking ending like its predecessor. Some may complain that the formula is becoming boring and stale, but it is still a perfectly decent addition to the franchise.  As a fan of the Dead Space series, I found F.E.A.R. 3 to have a commanding presence when it comes to atmosphere. I would argue that F.E.A.R. 3 nails the atmosphere and overall eerie-filled environments better than Dead Space 3. The attentional to detail is more adequate in some areas than others, but it has enough going in that department to earn a ribbon.   The gunplay is rock-solid, which makes gameplay worthwhile. Along with the cover system that lets you peek while in cover, quickly lean to the opposite side and aim, it nails the cover-system just right. For those that are looking for a more conventional F.E.A.R. 3 tactic and approach to gameplay, it is still all there and nothing much has changed if you want to use slow-mo and the run-and-gun variety.   Even on the easiest difficulty, F.E.A.R. 3 can present some difficulty spikes. A franchise that basically expects a player to run-and-gun using the slow-mo function, you could be taken down quickly on normal difficulty. It asks you to be tactical while using slow-mo. It is slightly different from F.E.A.R. 1 in that you are not only running into singular rooms, using slow-mo, and unloading. There are plenty of cover usage so you will need to run from one cover to another while using slow-mo. Think of it as a Chinese action film with lots of gun-fighting. It can be quite satisifying at times, but the variation comes in with using cover to get to where you need to go without dying outright. I hear it is a common complaint among the series' fans, but I did not find a major issue with it.  F.E.A.R. 3 is far from great and it is worth noting that it is not spectacular as the original F.E.A.R. Either way, it manages to be a perfectly decent addition to the series without presenting any major quams. It is successful at being a solid first-person shooter with the well-known F.E.A.R. elements. While I cannot comment on the co-operative play because I have no experience in it, F.E.A.R. 3 offers enough there to warrant a purchase on a decent sale.   I paid $5 for it and I thought that it was worth it. I cannot say for sure if it would have been worth $10 though.   It's a rock-solid game to the series. Just do not expect another F.E.A.R. 1 and you will enjoy it for what it offers.   Game on, Elann  Rating: 7 out of 10

Summary:  If you are looking for a FPS, buy this.  If you are looking for a F.E.A.R game, don't buy this. (I like it). -Will catch you up on the story if you havn't played the first 2 installments (Extraction Point and Perseus Mandate excluded).  Negative:  -The graphics seem a backward step from F.E.A.R 2. -The story is contradictory and dissapointing.  -It tries to be scary and falls short unlike previous installments. -Much easier than past 2 installments by taking on a generic health system (I'M LOOKING AT YOU COD), you recover health instead of trying to scavenge it and armour. -I don't know who thought it would be a good idea to introduce a point based challenge system in order to 'level up'. -'A lot' of reiteration of previous F.E.A.R story points. -Do not understand the Replicas' 'deal' this game. -Alma?

F.E.A.R. 3 is a First Person Horror Shooter.  It continues the story line of F.E.A.R. 1 and 2 but here you are again the protagonist from the first game. The Point Man, one of Almas childs. And actually you can play 2 characters, the other one being Paxton Fettel, the other son of Alma, but only when you have finished the game once. There are 2 different endings. The first, which is probably the 'real' ending is the good one of the Point Man and the other one is the Evil end of Paxton Fettel.  The Story itself is easy explained. You have to reach Alma because she is giving birth to her new child. But this is a hard and stony way especially because you have to escape from a prison first but because both brothers working together it works. Working together more or less. But beside you are hunted by your bad memories of your childhood which feature Harlan Wade, the 'father' of Alma. Saying father is this case is an insult because he is a real ****, well you know what I mean. You have to forget your memories of Harlan Wade.  On your way you pass many levels and especially different ones! No level looks the same and this is actually what was really amazing! Never saw so much variety and nice design in the levels. Pretty much the best from all F.E.A.R. games but this is probably the only aspect thats better compared to other games, sadly. The game implemented a new Health system what I like to call CoD illness. Really annoying and I missed the Medipacks and armor. It wasnt that bad after all but seriously, why did you have to add this feature to a F.E.A.R. game? There is also a new level system which I like to call CoD level illness. You get XP for getting Kill rewards or collecting things. Never liked it but to be honest its not that bad implemented here. With 'ranking' up you also get new Skills or upgrades. While playing this game I noticed that this game is pretty much build up for Multiplayer or Coop. Annoyed me a bit to be honest, I hate games where Singleplayer campaigns doesnt feel like Singleplayer campaigns. For me this game was a little bit difficult sometimes, I played on Normal difficulty. But this difficulty was more because of the damn bloodscreen. I hate this and it makes the game hectic. The scare level is a little bit less I have to say but there were still some nice level parts which scared me. Not as many as before though. You are not hunted by Alma in this game anyway. Alma got nearly friendly, I really like how the developers changed Alma. For me she was never that evil anyway, I even liked her. She had just a bad history.  [SPOILER!] (I try to let them out but in this case I have to say it because its a bad thing for me about the game) But what really made me sad is the fact that Alma dies in the end anyway, why letting the main character die like this? If you play the game you know what I mean. A really stupid and wasted death for Alma. I hope her child can offer us a similar experience in F.E.A.R. 4, if it will be ever released. Cant tell actually. Maybe this was the final game. Also Becket dies in a poor and questionable way... WHY? This didnt even make any sense. Especially how they made Becket. I mean the 1-2 minutes he actually appears in a cutscene. Yeah, the character was silent in F.E.A.R. 2 but here they just made him like a poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ which wants to end his miserable life. Couldnt they make something more interesting like he teamed up with Alma or something? Its his child after all... Bad decision. They could have made the story so much better.  The graphics of the game are ok but nothing special. Similar to F.E.A.R. 2s graphics.  It has to be said that this game was developed by another studio, not Monolith. Monolith just provided some help. The main developer was Day 1 Studios. Noticeable concerning the changes but wasnt that bad for a indie sort of developer.  I had time to play the campaign in coop with my girlfriend. It was actually a little bit more enjoyable in coop, especially playing with Fettel. First time I played with him and it was a completely different gameplay. You can actually move into enemies bodies and control them. This is only for a limited time though. But you can extend it with collecting their souls after they die. When you are not inside of an enemy you can shoot some sort of projectiles from your hand. You can also grab your enemies from far away. I actually had quite some fun playing in Coop. In the end there is a comparison of the statistics of both players and who actually wins the playthrough. This characters ending is played then. I personally felt like Fettel was more powerful than the Pointman. Unbalanced maybe, no clue. This is where the game actually proper shines in my opinion. And this is actually the only reason for me to replay it sometimes... Never the less, Singleplayer is just mediocre.  Postitive: - Nice variety of environments in levels - Solid shooter gameplay, little bit similar to F.E.A.R. 2s. - Some scares, not as many as before - Good Coop - Fettel is a interesting gameplay character  Negative: - Too... Much... CoD... - Levels/Ranks useless beside of Coop - Questionable story decisions - Singleplayer is kinda boring, made for Coop... - 5 Hour campaign - Graphics outdated (2011) - Soundtrack is different and worse - Probably the last F.E.A.R. ever... F.E.A.R. Online just made it worse.  Replayability: Only for Coop  Well, thats everything that needs to be said I think. F.E.A.R. 3 was a good game for me but with a little bitter taste, especially at the end. It didnt feel like a proper F.E.A.R. anymore. Only replayable for Coop. The story is actually kind of disappointing. The devs totally wasted a lot of potencial here. Why did Monolith give this game away to another developer? Seriously? Actually I feel like they killed the franchise with this action. Or maybe it was WB who wanted to milk the franchise to death? I hope you take responsibility for this Monolith or WB. This is how you NOT do it. Well, the devs of F.E.A.R. 3 still did somewhat a solid job, even if the end product is far away from the quality of the first 2 F.E.A.R.s.  My rating would be 6.5/10 points. The other games, except the addons/dlcs got always better ratings. I think this is a fair score and I cant give more without feeling to overrate it.

I have played the F.E.A.R. trilogy on the Xbox 360, as well as the PC. (However I have yet to finish this one yet on the PC). So here is how I feel about this game.  As a shooters, is a fun game. The gun mechanics feel nice. The guns themselves feel nice. Hell, if you have a good PC running this at max settings, they look gorgeous. And I like the co-op-slash-competitive mode this game does. Whoever gets the highest score, becomes the 'favorite' son to Alma. And you also level up in this game which increase stuff like ammo capacity, slo-mo, and whatever else.  However, as a F.E.A.R. game, it is terrible. And that's why I don't recommend this for F.E.A.R. fans. F.E.A.R. 3 is the weakest installment of the series, lacking everything that made the first two great. Even F.E.A.R. 2, however others feel about it, was still faithful to the first one than this. The developers have essentionally made this as Call of Duty: Psychic Warfare.  First, you are now relying on auto regen for your, now apparently low health bar. You used to be tough in previous installments, and need to find health kits to restore your health. Which was one of the things I have liked about this series. Now you can't even step out of cover without needing to GET BACK INTO cover after getting hit with a few bullets. (I'm exaggerating here, but the point is, they have basically nerfed your HP.)  (Edit: I want to add really quick that I am playing this on normal difficutly. In case you're wondering if I was playing it in hard mode.)  Secondly, the fear isn't there anymore. The game used to get you spooked with it's atmosphere. As supposed to the cheap jump scares studios typically do. (Which, there are some in previous installments, but they weren't heavily reliant.) Oh yeah, speaking of which, this one doesn't even have that. The atmosphere is gone. Now is just another generic first person shooter.  Now, in case you're thinking, 'But what about the slo-mo? F.E.A.R. is known for that?' So were Max Payne and True Crime. Doesn't mean anything if the game itself is still bad, does it? Yeah, it's there, but it's not like it saved this game.  So overall, this is a disappointing installment. And this is after I said that it's a fun game. Perhaps if this was a different game, like say, a sequel to Blacklight, (Not counting Blacklight: Retribution) I could have given this a more positive review. Because it is a fun shooter. Generic or otherwise.  If you're still thinking about buying this to see for yourself, I say wait for a steam sale, or, if you still have an Xbox 360 or PS3, see if you can find a copy for cheap. They should be around $10 or less by now.

It soon becomes apparent, though, that the story really is getting old - it just lacks mystery and suspense.   To make matters worse, the game seems to have completely missed the mark on the horror side. It tries to scare, but just doesn't. Towards the end of the game you start to get tired of boring story sequences interrupting the action!   So what are you left with? Well, a good urban warfare shooter, albeit a little short. It still comes highly recommended, but I'm afraid that if you have expectations for this game being a 'horror', you will feel let down. It's still one of the few true coop games around, and the coop is a great deal of fun, so it deserves recommendation on that fact alone. Just don't pay too much for it!

And alas we come full circle with the F.E.A.R series with F.E.A.R 3 or F.3.A.R if you're a fan of bad names. F.E.A.R 3 contructs its campaign to be a co-op based afair compared to the other games in the series, so it's best you play it with a buddy as I did. Gameplay remains much the same if you play as Pointman complete with slo-mo gunfighting and all. Fettell on the other hand is the more interesting character to play as he has some neat abilities like possession and suspending enemies. Story is pretty bare bones even for a F.E.A.R game with no really interesting character interactions except the dialogue between the brothers occasionally. The biggest flaw however is that the game is criminally short, like 4 hours total to beat all 8 intervals. Also the horror has taken a further backseat with the introduction of co-op. Overall whilst F.E.A.R 3 isn't a bad game, it's actually a fun co-op game to play with a friend, it's a bad F.E.A.R game compared to the others in the series.

Here's the deal, F.E.A.R. 3 is nothing like the other two entires. Remotely. It is a Call-of-Dutified entry to the series which has its fair share of 'F.E.A.R. moments', though at a caveat, being delivered with a horribly inconsistent difficulty and a tedious combat system. As far as its story goes, it is passable, with none of the bells and whistles of the original two games with their expansive 'voicemail messages' (F.E.A.R.) and 'intel documents' (F.E.A.R. 2). Ending = crap. Also to be noted is the increasingly nauseating gore-factor, which is not for the weak of heart (or stomach). The graphics are pretty average, the sound effects atmospheric, though interrupted consistently by the in-game achievements (terribly, terribly integrated). That's right, the constantly popping achievements (in-game, not Steam) are one of my greatest gripes, as it really draws from the experience, as you could imagine, though thankfuly, this is not too much of an experience to be missed.  6/10

It's a shame FEAR 3 didn't sell. But I understand why. I'm a huge fan of the original FEAR developed by Monolith Productions, but its expansion packs developed by Timegate were not very good. Then FEAR 2 was lackluster, and Monolith made that one themselves! When FEAR 3 was announced as a Day One Studios title, we all sort of wrote it off. But it's the best pure FPS of 2011.  Part 1 opted for J-Horror stylings. FEAR 3 doesn't attempt to be scary and fail. It just doesn't attempt. This is fine, because the thing I like about FEAR was its gunplay. The guns, the quite competent enemy squad AI, the slow motion effects. FEAR 3 brings this all back to form (2 felt a bit too 'console-y') with two additions. The cover system is thankfully quite non-intrusive and doesn't reduce the game to 'whack-a-mole' a la Gears of War. Co-op play is where it's at. In fact, the game is built for it. Don't play any other way or you may find it impossible. Note: the 2nd player has slightly superior powers.

♥ Diverse levels.  I'm not one to mind repeating levels/maps in games however it's clear that they put effort into the design of Fear's world. I quite liked how each chapter was a change from the last...you explore a variety of buildings and are put into a number of situations, instead of facing the same boss over and over again, or being forced into a series of mazes.   Diversity in its design is a strong virtue of Fear 3.   ♥ Made me jump.  Though Fear 3 isn't nearly as scary as the past titles, it did have several spooky moments in it. Granted I'm a total scaredy cat yet who wouldn't jump at an angry little girl leaping at them while they're climbing up a ladder? ; _ ;   ♥ Enjoyable co-op.  Whenever someone has wanted to play a co-op game with me, I used to always suggest playing Fear 3 together. Why? For one the co-op is balanced, a fact that I appreciate. Unlike other games it has both players doing equal amount of work and requires teamwork without going overboard.  For another, I liked how the average time to beat the game, at least for my friends and I, was around 8 to 12 hours. I liked having a game to invest time into without having to play it week after week with someone. I understand others have found the main story lacking time wise yet this was never a problem for me.  In case you're bored or finish the main storyline, there are four, multiplayer, mini games to play. Very fun!   ✘ The story IS lacking.   I can understand people who value games by looking at all aspects - the sound, the story, the graphics, etc. I can also understand people who have the view of looking for one thing, excellent graphics, beautiful music, and the like above all else. For me what matters most is the story of a game.   Compared to the other Fear titles, I agree that Fear 3 is lacking in its story. They could have taken it so much farther than they did - I found the relationship between the two main characters was filled with possibility that they seemed to purposely shove aside. I don't believe we need to be pirvy to every aspect of a character, however they made them seem like cardboard cut outs, instead of real...Humans, ghosts, aliens, there was no difference for they all acted flat and emotionally frigid.   Not once when I've replayed Fear 3 have I ever felt a connection to any of them nor have I felt pulled in by the story. As scary as I found the first Fear to be, it DID pull me into the story and the world of Alma. The dev team had so much they could have worked with backstory wise, relationships between characters, etc. and used none of it. I'll stick to fanfiction to get an emotional high... ' - '   ✘ Very hard to play with motion sickness.  As my motion sickness has gotten worse, I've had to give up playing many games, Fear 3 among them. Despite its flaws, I have always enjoyed the game, and would replay it every few months. If anyone suffering from motion sickness is thinking about buying it, I would strongly advice you to think twice, for the game isn't kind to those who suffer from it!   ✘ I think the main reason people are let down with Fear 3 is when they buy it thinking it's going to be a horror game. Does it have jump scares? Yes. Is it spooky? To me it is. However unlike the others in the series, I consider Fear 3 a shooter/survival game more than anything. It's wonderful if you're looking for a co-op game, no fault there, but as a horror game? Not so much. Still it might give you a spook or two!  Overall if you're looking for a co-op game, Fear 3 would make a wonderful choice. If you're considering it from the aspect of loving the Fear series, I'd skip it.

I've been meaning to complete the FEAR anthology for some time now having played the original FEAR some years ago, so when they came on sale for the anthology I couldn't resist. I'll admit I've played (approximately) half of the original FEAR, and completed FEAR 3, so I will only reveal story information without ending spoilers pertaining to FEAR 3.  You start out nine months after the ending of the first two games, captured protagonist known as the point man held in south america works to escape with the assistance of Paxton Fettel after interrogation. Brothers in arms Point Man who is the Wolverine-like protagonist and Paxton a spectre. During their escape, they discover that they are being hunted along with their mother, Alma. The creature seeking to kill the family was created based on the evil memories of the mother, and this evil has formed a strange paranoia over Fairport. In order to restore the balance, the brothers set out to destroy any memories associated to the past to weaken the monster hunting them.  The game sets a good base story and introduces a very cool horror element. There was some supernatural element introduced that didn't really fit but the actual horror side of the supernatural was a perfect buttery fit and it got a couple of good jumps from me. The story is particularly hard to follow until you get three quarters in but once you get there the story and gameplay make much more sense and the game goes from being somewhat random to making sense.  After completing all but the last few chapters, the game really picks up and becomes a lot more fun. The horror elements in the last chapter were the highlight as the story became very clear in this chapter and it really felt like an action horror where as the rest of the game was scattered between action and horror but never the two. The game is short, sweet, but it's also lacking in story and fun comparring to its original - of which I recall having a lot of fun in my youth. I have heard from a lot of people complaining that this game fell short of its original, I can agree and understand, but there's no denying you'll have fun in this game because you will.  I feel it more of a casual game due to the points system, it feels like it was created for its points system and not its story. Yje lack of story in the beginning, the point system and its linearity all contribute to the downgrade of this games reception to me. It does become repetitive when all you need to do is shoot until everybody is dead, move into next section and repeat the entire game. I have an issue with that, but there's no real interaction or immersive features.  It's a solid game and it runs well on old technology. Getting a jump or two makes you smile, and the whole composure results in a great story and a lot of fun.

Ugh. See my FEAR and FEAR2 reviews for necessary context, but the pros are few and far between here:  1) Even better graphics, but lackluster, repetitive and at times confusing level design.  2) Genuinely bad AI. It also seemed like there was some fairly cheesy enemy spawning going on, and while it was sometimes hard to tell, there is no doubt that the scary-good AI of the original game is gone for good.  3) Gunplay is definitely a serious regression from FEAR and FEAR2. Everything has a very arcadey feel to it now, which is only compounded by the braindead AI and level layouts. Plus, you can only carry two weapons and a small number of grenades, and your health now regenerates. I play games like this INSTEAD of Call of Duty and the like, since they reduce the difficulty and tension pretty drastically for me. Walked into an ambush and are on the verge of death? No problem! Just crouch behind a box for a few seconds, emerge from cover in slow-mo, and faceroll the AI.  4) Achievements. Why are there achievements unlocking in-game, in real time, as I play a story-driven horror FPS? Immersion is critical in games like this, and fewer things take me out of that more than random unlocks for 'X slow-mo kills' or the like popping up on my screen during firefights or scare moments. Too much of this felt like priming players to jump into MP, rather than to enjoy the SP mode.  5) Not at all scary. There are definitely some disturbing and interesting revelations, but many of the plot developments are spoon-fed to the player, rather than being discovered and experienced organically. Even the things that do come about more naturally still felt forced on some level and certainly weren't frightening.  6) The game's final act is a huge disappointment story-wise. Again, I don't want to spoil it verbatim here, but I did not feel that the Point Man's 'good ending'--which I view as the game's intended ending--really made that much sense. We never really understand the mind-state of Alma, and nor is her resolution or the implications of the child ever really made clear. Fettel's 'bad' ending certainly followed more logically, so perhaps its more apocalyptic and nihilistic tenor is truer to the nature of the series overall.  Sadly, this game largely self-destructed where it counts, leading to a rather unenjoyable and ignoble end to what could and should have been a great series. Take a pass and go play the original FEAR again instead.

The main reason I'm saying go for this game (preferably on sale) is because it gives closure to the story started back in the first F.E.A.R. I remember seeing the commercials on TV for this game and apparently had a misconception about how having Fettel as a secondary character would be. Day 1 did some neat things with the game differently from Monolith, but ultimately I think they fell short of realizing the true potential of the game.   I will say that I did not play the co-op portion at all...mostly because I had no one to play with. That being said, I did complete the single-player mode, and unlocked Fettel on all missions to replay through again. I did start this, but quickly lost interest, as the dialogue and almost everything about the game seemed quite repetitive, except you see cut scenes from Fettel's point of view. I think the game itsefl could have had some awesome variety, as well as some extra gameplay time added for first play-through if the story involved using both characters and switching back and forth depending on the mission or circumstances.  The graphics I thought were much better, the control scheme vastly different, but I got used to it. I do feel the realism factor increased in fighting by using the reddening screen and then letting the Point Man recover (I'm assuming part of his meta/super-humaness involved an accelerated healing factor). Sometimes it gets old searching for health packs.  I can't say I was super happy with the ending, but I wasn't disappointed either. The story seemed to be building up to some amazing climax, but in the end just left me feeling sorry for Alma and wondering if she just wanted someone to be kind to her all along. The cultish aspect of some of the later levels was a little disturbing, but that seemed to be more of where Fettel's character was going as well. There's definitely plenty of blood. Blood on the walls, blood flying from gunshots, knife kills, dripping from bodies and oozing from everyone you meet practically.   I was startled a couple of times....never overly scared...  The variety of antagonists in the game was definitely a little more varied than in F.E.A.R. 2, but I'm guessing because Alma's power was at a max and everyone and everything was being affected more drastically. Some of the goons you fight were more annoying than anything, and I started to get bored with fighting Replica Commanders very quickly.  If it's on sale, then definitely pick it up, but I wouldn't pay $20 for it.

Despite all the hate coming from people, F3AR is enjoyable in its own right. Granted, gameplay was streamlined too much compared to the sequels that it feels too much like Cowadoodee (but not completely).  For one, medkits are gone and regenerating health is the new heals BUT unlike COD, regenerating health can bite you in the ♥♥♥ also as enemies do like to punish you hard (as in if they're not understrength, they WILL push towards you while trying to regen health). So no medkit abuse to get out of a fight where you're guaranteed dead.  Gunplay is a bit generic, but still enjoyable. You do have a destructible cover system that allows you to shoot from side to side, allowing for limited tactical gameplay. Its not original, but workable enough. The martial arts that the first game had and the second game downplayed, are now gone, however, which is a huge damn shame, because ♥♥♥♥ knives, I wanna punch and kick every person I can find like John Woo from hell.  There's also a unique feature in F3AR in that you can play as the pointman's sociopathic brother: Paxton Fettel. On his own, he can only throw out telekinetic bolts and levitate thiungs and can't use guns. He can, however, posses certain enemy troops for a limited amount of time, allowing you to have your meat puppet wreak havoc on the enemy lines before doing it again. He can also make people's heads explode like in Scanners. If you can find a friend to play Co-Op with, the prospect is quite good.  The atmosphere (after the first level) has to be one of the best features of the game. You do feel like in an apocalyptic wasteland after a psychic/nuclear disaster. It's not 'depressingly beautiful' or 'adrenalin-pumping beautiful' but just creepy. The more you progress, the more you see how horrifying Fairport has gone down under. People are crazy. Cannibalistic crazy. And the locations you venture through will reveal how high the level of crazy went into this place.  As for difficulty, F3AR does have it. ATC Black Ops and the Replica troops are tough that they usually take a few hits to take down, have a kiiiinda decent set of tactics. Though, the AI does kinda shift from Competent to Call of Duty at times, but most of the time, they remain competent and will give you a run for your money. Cannibal AI is not that far from your everyday zombies from L4D and the likes, but they will try sneak attacks as much as possible.  As for multiplayer. Its pretty much dead. Unless you have friends. Its dead.  Overall, F3AR might be a bit shifty with its price of $10, but is a definite buy if its on sale. It'll give you some decent enjoyment for its price.

This game deviates from everything that made the original FEAR and it's expansions great. You were the ultimate bad ♥♥♥ but you had to think and use all the tools available to defeat the smart AI. Levels in the original have branching path ways and felt like real places with boosters to collect to make your health and reflexes better. Varying enemy types had a heavier pressence in a battle, HEavy troopers would come through the wall while grunts out flank you. Now we have wave after wave of dumb always reacting the same soldiers. I believe that during the production meetings they developed all of the shooter elements and while making the horror someone said, 'Just throw some scary crap in there. The game is called FEAR right?'. So sorry to say but FEAR 3 is lame, buy the original and its expansions Extraction Point and Perseus Mandate, for shooters that actually feel good to play.

One day I decided to play all the FEAR games front to back, I started with FEAR 1, still as goo as I remembered it and the graphics are still decent for its age. I then played the DLC which I learned are non canon. They felt like singleplayer mods for the base game but a large part is just as good as the original game. FEAR 2 felt like a more streamlined version of the original which is a comon strategy in the gaming world. If a new IP does well the second game will be more streamlined, even if it didn't need to be.  I then played FEAR 3, I immediatly noticed the weak gun sounds, the aweful movement and the damage feedback on you, there is no damage feedback. While in the previous games when you get hit you would at least get a camera shake or a noise indicating you're taking damage in this game you can take damage without noticing it. Sure there's a damage indicator near your crosshair and your screen slowly turns red but you take such a huge amount of damage often times you just stand there taking damage shooting at the enemy right in front of you who also takes quite a bit of damage.  Compare this to FEAR 1 in which the gunplay was excellent, the gunsounds felt like they packed a punch, the dust and debris flying off walls and decoration made a firefight feel genuine and while enemies in the original did take a lot of damage firefights were fun. You had to take cover and the slow motion was a helpful feature. In FEAR 3 it's not really needed as you don't have to take cover that much.  FEAR 1 was a semi tactical shooter in which you couldn't just attack the enemy without thinking, you had to take cover, fall back and use the slow motion.  Also somehow FEAR 3 looks worse than any of the previous games, sure the textures might be higher but there doesn't seem to be a lot of dynamic lighting and everything looks brown. The movement feels weird, it might be the little momentum or the lack of movement feedback but it was much better in the previous games.  The bottom line is, the game feels like a budget title, the entire character of the FEAR games was stripped away and replaced with a generic budget shooter with slow motion tacked on. I won't play this game again and will not finish it.

F.E.A.R 3 is not a bad game. It's just a bad F.E.A.R game.  It's a prime example of what happens when a game is paced as a sprint. The game focuses so much on combat that it loses all the elements other than basic mechanics that made the series special.   Because of the focus on constant action, anything that attacks you in F.E.A.R 3 will scream or shoot on sight. There are no paranormal entities or Replica Assasins stealthily hunting you outside of one scripted sequence in the beginning of a single stage. There are also very few breaks in the action for horror events compared to the tense pacing breaks of the previous titles. Overall, there's no tension, no interesting characters, and a hollow story that's only tangentally related to the gameplay.   F.E.A.R 3 is still an enjoyable ride of slow-mo head shootin', but that's all it is. For a series fan I'd say this game is a pass, but for someone who wants to do some stylish killing in slow-motion then I'd say F.E.A.R 3 is worth picking up on sale.
